posts.name: Quentin C.
posts.cooked:
It would be amazing to have more camera features, such as but not limited to:

  • to have a self-timer for the picture
  • the possibility to record a video without maintaining the finger on the record button.
  • using the different lenses on a phone

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: Looking at apps such as OpenCamera there are so many more features people might want to add for the camera (such as take a picture two seconds after I make a loud noice) it might be better to just leave advanced features up to those specialised apps
Just use the default camera app by provided by your device.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Nice features for Signal in 3 years when theyâ€™ve finished all base feature development and cleaned up the app significantly. This is going to be extremely low on the list when the stock camera app is going to provide this functionality way better than Signal can.

posts.name: ðŸ‘ŠðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ðŸ”¥
posts.cooked: Youâ€™re better off using the default camera app. Signal strips the metadata whether the media is taken in-app or outside of it (when you send it via Signal).

Textra also has a built-in camera app that has fewer functions than my default camera app. However, I can long-press on the Textra camera button and it will launch the default camera app instead. Currently a long-press on the Signal camera app does nothing.

Although I can appreciate the convenience of the features you have mentioned, I personally prefer Signal as a feature limited but uncompromisingly security first message/voice/video communications app.

CueHD:

Currently a long-press on the Signal camera app does nothing.

It used to be possible to access the phoneâ€™s camera app from within Signal, but they did a redesign of the media flow that eliminated it. The idea is that the camera through Signal doesnâ€™t write anything unencrypted to disk, which is not true for the phoneâ€™s camera app. Unfortunately, fancy camera features can be difficult to implement and arenâ€™t the primary goal of a text messaging app, so itâ€™s not going to do as much as other apps that are available.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: Loving GrapheneOS where this isnâ€™t a concern.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: In GrapheneOS you donâ€™t have to worry about apps having access to all of your storage or media due to Storage Scopes.
Isnâ€™t that what the current Storage Access Framework for Android accomplishes?
i want these functionality, i can make a merge request if want?
